title: Charmry Pendants
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I am testing project Charmr by Autodesk.  
It is pretty basic displacement service with quite primitive shapes, but I somehow like it.  
There are a couple of stl's attached and a png file so you can play with Charmr youself.

comments.text: Do you have problems with the charms sticking to much to your build plate? Do you have any recommendations for print settings?
comments.author: rculmer

comments.text:
Use a sticking band (whichever it is called) on your plate and don't use a raft so a back surface is flat and smooth. When using a band, I usually increase a temp to 240 for better sticking of the first layers. I also pose a building plate quite close to a nozzle and than, after first few layers, I widen the distance by unloosing the bolts with a quarter of a round at a time.
Alternatively, don't use a band, but follow the procedure above.
comments.author: rculmer

comments.text: Your charm is very smooth looking. What are the setting you used when you exported your charm to print it. Did you use a makerbot?
comments.author: rculmer

comments.text: If you are referring to a purple image, it is a rendered image, not actual print.
comments.author: rculmer

comments.text: The great thing about Charmry is that they can be printed right away, no additional checks are needed. But the models are small, so use .1 mm layer heigth to reveal fine details. It takes one hour to print at .1 mm.
comments.author: pmarxx

Another spool holder! This is a spool holder that clips onto the top of a Prusa. Desiged for compact, 90mm wide, 2kg spools.
Clips on easily and easy to remove. The filament is dispensed inline with the X axis, so it comes off the spool easier with less flexing and rattling.

Press two 608 bearings into bearing retainers. Two size of bearing retainers are provided, for 40mm and 30mm spool holes.
Sandwich the spool between the retainers with a 150mm long 5/16 thread rod, held in place on both sides by 5/16 nuts.
Screw the Spool Arms to the Clip-on Base using #4 X 1/2" countersink wood screws.
Gentle spread the Clip-on Base and clip it to the top thread rods of your Prusa.
Place the spool assembly on top of the Spool Arms. Secure it to the arms with a 5/16 nut on each side. I print my parts 2 perimters, 2 solid layers and 0.3 fill density.

description.text:
This is a model of the bottom part of the cup holder in the Mini Cooper.
It's really a starting point for me, I plan on creating a modified one for use as more than just a cup holder. I also plan to make one without the overhangs for easier printing.

title: Prusa i3 Single Sheet Frame Filament Guide

description.text: This is another filament guide for the Prusa i3. I wanted one that did not restrict movement of the filament along the X-axis too much and provided a slot large enough to make it easy to thread.

If your frame width is 6.3mm, download the .stl and print with 10% infill and 2 shells. Otherwise, download the .scad file and change the slot to match your frame width, compile, and export your own .stl file.

author: oliasmage

description.text: Redesigned  madkites version of whistle. Increased heigh. Added 1mm hem and 2mm edge for better bridging. Increased hold. Pea is bigger and with hollow (lighter). Stl file is exported with bigger precision (its more then 100mb in size).
Im printing on hardened glass with ABS from german grrf. Best results are with speed 32mm/s (0,8 on loop) and 0.25 layer height. bridge coeficients are 1.0 feed, 2.0 flow rate.

comments.text: Ifter 2 years i have prnted another pieces and found little problem with this wistle design.  I took  the shape of the slot from another whistle design and remodelled rest.  Some printed pieces did not sound and I thought it was too sparse print (air blows throu). But it was not exact true. Main problem was too tight slot. If u choose different setting of "inset surface" on your cam program(im  usiing kisslicer now), it will dramaticaly change shape of thin walls. Setting 0 leads to exact slot size (not sounding whistle) while inset set to 1/2 of extrusion width make 3mm larger slot and whistle sounds perfectly.
comments.author: Zemciko

comments.text: Printed in PLA, with Cura and Ultimaker. Looks good, but makes no sound for me either. I assume the design is critical.
comments.author: egil

comments.text: All my "nonsounding" pieces were from pla and all of them were not 100% "solid" (when i try blow to them and plug hole some air still go fhrou..). Design is ok, well printed whistle works same as from ABS.
comments.author: egil

comments.text:
I think i have solved the problem with PLA whistle do not working. Problem was print quality. Altough whistle looked fine on first view, on second view i noticed that not working whistles were not fully solid. If i plug upper hole and blow to whistle, air still come throu... After printing with better parametres (0.25layer 220
Ã‚Â°C 100% infill) whistle works fine even from PLA. Btw i will upload smaller model of same whestle as well. Printed result looks similar to me from both models and its only 2MB big...
comments.author: Zemciko

comments.text: Ok i have printed one whistle from clear PLA and it does not work. I have bunch of identical whistles printed from ABS with different print quality, and all of them work fine. Size looks similar... Any idea why ABS work and PLA not?
comments.author: Zemciko

comments.text: Weird, i have made about 10 pieces and all of them work fine. (All of them from clear ABS). Mac gyver, is ur pea inside still welded to whistle or already mechanicaly breaked off, as intended?

This is an axial flux generator designed to be printed on a RepRap/Makerbot or similar, with a small build envelope. It features (more-or-less) toolless assembly. Get the OpenSCAD source here: https://github.com/haydnv/mark1
This generator uses rare earth magnets, so be extremely careful when putting it together—you can easily lose a finger or worse if one magnet attracts another while your hand is in the way.

• 16 1/4" x 4" ID x 8" OD rare earth wedge magnets; you can get these from magnet4less.com or aliexpress.com if you're outside the US.
  • About 5lbs (2kg) of 18AWG (19SWG) copper magnet wire; you can get this from bulkwire.com.
  • 2 thrust bearings, 60mm ID x 85mm OD x 17mm high
  • 1 tube of gasket sealant from any hardware store
  • Wire cutters (scissors will do in a pinch)
  • Electrical tape
  • Optionally: kapton tape and a soldering iron
  • If you don't have a soldering iron, you'll need wire ties and medium-grain sandpaper (I recommend the sandpaper regardless)
  • 2 rotor plates in 3mm stainless steel; the cheapest way to get these is to order them from someone with a CNC mill, which is completely dependent on where you're located. The cheapest online 3D printer for stainless steel is ponoko, but it's still very expensive (>$500)
  • 16 rotor.stl pieces, printed
  • 16 rotor_edge_tie.stl pieces, printed
  • 4 rotor_peg.stl pieces, printed
  • 6 stator.stl pieces, printed
  • 6 chuck.stl pieces, printed
  • 2 support.stl pieces, printed (these are used in winding the induction coils and are not present in the finished product)
  • 1 rotor_cap.stl piece, printed—I highly recommend you customize this to your application

• Put one rotor plate on the floor.
  • Put one magnet in a rotor piece and slide it under the plate.
  • Secure the assembly with a rotor edge tie.
  • Repeat steps 2 and 3 until you have all 8 spaces filled. Make certain that you place the magnets such that each magnet attracts ones beside it.
  • Use gasket sealant around the circumference of the rotor, where the plastic meets the metal (inside circumference and outside circumference) and leave the rotor at least 2-3 hours for the sealant to cure.
  • Repeat steps 1-4 for the other rotor plate. KEEP THE TWO ROTOR PLATES FAR APART for now; they will be extremely strongly magnetically attracted to each other.

• Place a chuck between the two winder supports.
  • Thread the end of your magnet wire spool through the end of the chuck. Leave plenty of extra wire (like 20cm) on the end because you'll need to connect it to a coil on the opposite side of the stator later.
  • Wind an induction coil by rotating the supports. Stop when the edge of the coil meets the edge of the support.
  • Clip the wire leading to your spool. Again, make sure to leave plenty of extra wire for later.
  • Immediately after removing the supports, keep pressure on the coil with your hand and wrap it with two pieces of electrical tape so it will retain its shape.
  • Repeat steps 1-4 six times to form 6 induction coils.
  • Place each induction coil in a stator piece and put the stator pieces together (it will be obvious how they fit if you put each one face-up on the floor oriented like they were when you printed them).
  • Remove the insulative coating at each tip of the wire using the sandpaper (recommended) or soldering iron (easy to do but do not inhale the vapor)
  • To wire the generator in star configuration, you will need 3 of the induction coils to have their starting wire (the part threaded through the chuck) pointing out through the stator notch. Call these the A coils. The other 3 coils need their ending wire (the part you clipped from the spool) pointing out. Call these the B coils. Set them up like this now—you may want to label which is which because you'll need to remember for the next step.
  • Connect the outer ends of the A coils together to form the star point. I recommend you use a soldering iron for this, but you can also use a wire tie if you prefer.
  • Within the stator, connect the inner ends of the A coils to the inner ends of the B coils. You may need to trim some excess; go ahead and do so now. Your goal is to keep the inner connections as low-profile as possible so they don't interfere with the rotation of the generator.
  • Glue the stator pieces together with gasket sealant. You should secure the induction coils in place somehow—I recommend kapton tape, although gasket sealant will probably work as well.
  • Leave the stator at least 2-3 hours for the sealant to cure.

• Turn over one rotor such that the plastic side is facing up.
  • Place the stator on the rotor so that the center spaces on each line up.
  • Fit one thrust bearing into the center space. Make sure that it meshes with the rotor rather than sitting on top of it.
  • Place the second thrust bearing on top of the first. When lowering the second rotor half onto the bearing, take care to keep it aligned so that magnetic attraction doesn't dislodge the top of the bearing.
  • Lower the other rotor onto the stator, plastic-side down.
  • Fit the rotor cap to the top of the rotor, making sure the rotor peg holes line up with the holes in the rotor pieces, and glue around the perimeter with gasket sealant. Allow 2-3 hours to cure.
  • Flip the generator over, rotor cap down, and place 4 (or optionally up to 8) rotor pegs through the top rotor pieces, the opposite rotor pieces, and into the bottom of the rotor cap.
    • You now have a functioning 3-phase electrical generator!

comments.text:
well, i spent (well machine time ) hours and hours and hours making just one of each of the pieces ... now i realize i have to make multiple copies , as per your instructions and in the pic of the assembly, i can see about 6 of the stator holders that took about 1.5 hrs to print , EACH.
I think I'll contemplate something other than my apparently very slow printer !!!
comments.author: freNRG

comments.text: Did you use 14AWG or 19 SWG wire? According to this table http://www.bulkwire.com/wiregauge.asphttp://www.bulkwire.com/wirega... 14AWG is not equal to 19SWG but to 16 SWG. Also: In your picture the wire doesn't look like 14 AWG, but maybe 18 AWG which would equal 19SWG. The wire would be half as thick and cost much less...
comments.author: Trooner

comments.text: Whoops, good catch -- I used 19SWG. Just fixed the description.
comments.author: Trooner

comments.text: Please add some pictures of different stages while manufacturing.
comments.author: wetter

comments.text: Any one else thinks this kind of looks like the Arc generator from Iron Man? I'd say this makes the project even cooler by a factor of like, 20.
comments.author: Darthwahl

comments.text: Actually, When I built mine I put the magnets so they attracted their neighbor. This is nececasry as the N-S-N-S flux is what generates the alternating current that later needs to be rectified into DC. ;)
comments.author: JerZ

comments.text: For more info Google: Hugh Piggot Axial flux wind turbine 8-)
comments.author: JerZ

comments.text:
Were you using a dual rotor? I'm aware that the flux has to be through the coil to generate a voltage difference but in this design the flux is between the N
&
amp; S poles on opposite sides of the stator. Wouldn't the flux be horizontal (parallel to the stator) rather than vertical (through the stator) if I placed the magnets so they attracted their neighbor?
comments.author: JerZ

comments.text: This is a good illustration of what I'm talking about. See page 4.
comments.author: haydnv

comments.text: Fixed! Thanks.
comments.author: JerZ

comments.text: Do the rotor plates have to be a ferrous material?
comments.author: chugadie

comments.text: Ferrous metals are best as they help induce the magnetic circuit.
comments.author: chugadie

comments.text: Actually, you want everything but the coils to be non-ferrous dielectrics to gain the maximum power generation.
comments.author: JerZ

comments.text: That's fine but, we are talking about a magnetic circuit here, on page 4 of: http://www.windenergy.nl/website/files/artikelen/AXIAL_FLUX_HowItWorks.pdfhttp://www.windenergy.nl/websi... you can see it is explained that the magnetic flux is collected in the iron plate to be concentrated across the gap containing the coils. Although it is harder to see magnetic flux flows much like electricity and setting the system up in a circuit yields higher concentrations of flux through the coil. Bigger bang for your buck as it were. After spending $150 on magnets when I built mine I have tried both ways and ended up using 12" chop saw blades for rotors. Just mount it on something (5/8" rod?) so that it spins freely and hold an angle grinder too it next to the teeth. The blade will spin and it's teeth will be cut off in a perfect circle. Gloves and eye protection is a must, and don't ever try it. But it worked great for me. More like 18v with 9 coils and 12 magnets, but I can charge a 4 12v battery bank and run a small workshop off of a 2000Watt inverter, So it does work. Just not close to 1KW.
comments.author: MrElectrical

comments.text: JerZ, you can use a wet saw blade with a continuous rim - no teeth (if you have one lying around, they're quite expensive).
comments.author: JerZ

comments.text: What speed and/or torque was needed for 1KW?  What voltage was that at?
comments.author: mfinn

comments.text: Unfortunately I've only build one and it was damaged when my wind turbine fell over :( I'm putting it back together now and hope to have this question answered very soon. The theoretical power curve I've calculated suggests that it should reach 1KW with wind of around 9 m/s and a 2-meter swept diameter, but I don't know yet how that will play out in reality.
comments.author: mfinn

comments.text: Whenever you have the time, would you mind producing some more documentation on this?  Like which way the wedges have to be magnetically aligned (through thickness, through circumference, etc) as well as pole orientation?
comments.author: thantik

comments.text: Absolutely! The wedges are magnetized through thickness, as are all the wedge magnets you can get from the sources I've listed above. I believe pole orientation should be opposing within each rotor (magnets repel each other) such that the two rotors will attract when you put them together, but JerZ above sounds like he might know better...
You said in line 4 of "Rotor Assembly":
comments.author: haydnv

comments.text: Perfect as I was going to build one of these myself and you beat me to it.
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text:
How critical is the rotor plate in dimensions and material? Is hand cutting
&
amp; drill press holes on any ferrous metal ok if a good job is done?
comments.author: creuzerm

comments.text: The height (5mm) can vary and you can use any ferrous material as long as you're not afraid of rust. Hand-cutting and drilling would work if you're very precise, but it would be a lot of work!
comments.author: creuzerm

comments.text: Very intriguing, do you have a video?
comments.author: sirmakesalot

comments.text: I don't yet but I'm hoping to very soon.
comments.author: sirmakesalot

My latest obsession has been collecting, and subsequently photographing silver coins.  Coins have been one of the hardest subjects I've photographed.  Its just the begining of a long process, but I wanted to design something that would give me consistent, even and low angle lighting all the way around the coin.  Quick Rhino design later, some soldering and I'm in business!  Simple electronics, simple print, stunning results! Gives a nice focused light at the center. The coin pics I've included were actually shot with a webcam.  It was the easiest solution and provided the fastest feedback.  Eventually I'll get out the big rig and take some really hi-res images.  There is a cutout archway for sliding in coins that are already in graded slabs and an optional pedestal for open coins.
This light doubly functions as an odd little look through flashlight.  I've used it quite a few times in the network closets already!

The parts I used were bought locally at Radio Shack. Total $12, so you could certainly do it for half the cost if sourced online. (I'm too impatient) 4 - 5mm white LEDs
1 - soft touch spst switch
1 - 9V pigtail
1 - 9V battery
2 - 5mm x 25mm bolts and nuts
1 - Each of the included stl models. (You'll need to enable support when printing the innerRing.stl
Resistors, wire, heat shrink as needed. I also used Elmer's Tack. Its a removable Adhesive putty thats going to replace my hot glue gun. Soooooo much easier to work with. repositionable, sticky, insulates. Use http://ledcalculator.net/ takes all of the math out of the equation!! Put in the values for your LEDs and it spits out the needed resistors. I've got my LEDs way undervolted because they were a bit to bright. Maybe the second version I'll add a potentiometer. Dimensions:
Outside: 130mm
Inside: 90mm
Height: 30mm
LEDs are at 20mm from the deck
Pedestal is 15mm high Check out my dropbox for more photos: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/a6spp8tg14nes7k/QcrdbozHM6/silverLight

comments.text: Your sample picture is fantastic! I'm in the process of designing a ring flash for macro shots, and this gave me some solid ideas.
comments.author: reismj

comments.text: This is going to be a present a friend and jewelry maker, I often hear about lighting struggles. He has a really complex setup that takes loads of space.
comments.author: bitflusher

comments.text: Nice little project! I often need to photograph small parts and this might be good for that. What color/material did you use for the "lens"?
comments.author: JuliaTruchsess

comments.text: No lens on the project! The LEDs poke through the side. If I remember correctly, they have about a 30 degree spread. They actually cant down about 15 degrees so it ends up with a nice focused illumination center. Really simple
comments.author: JuliaTruchsess

comments.text: Ah. In the photo they totally look like they're behind a diffuser! Thanks :)

title: RepRepDiscount Full Graphic LCD Mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
This is an LCD panel mount for the Prusa i3 that mounts the RepRapDiscount full graphic LCD and similar clones to the top-left portion of the Prusa i3 frame.  
I found placing the LCD here to be the least likely place it could go and not be in the way of the axes movement.  
I hope you find similar joy.  
Note that you can combine this mount with a case for the LCD provided the case has mounting holes that correspond with the mounting holes on the LCD.   
However, I like the raw, mad scientist look of bare PCBs. ;)

Parts Required: (1) 4" 5/16 bolt
(1) 5/16" nut
(1) 5/16" washer
(4) 3mm x 10mm bolts
(2) 3mm x 20mm bolts
(6) 3mm nuts
(2) 3mm washers (optional) Instructions: 1) print out all parts
2) remove the (2) bolts holding your top left Z axis bracket
3) place base of the mount on top of frame and thread the 20mm bolts through the top Z-axis bracket and the base (see photo) then add 3mm washers and nuts and tighten
4) mount arms to the LCD panel with the spacer side pointing toward the center
5) thread the 5/16" bolt through the arms and base
6) adjust and tighten the 5/16" bolt
7) connect LCD panel ribbon cables

comments.author: oliasmage

comments.text: If you see strange characters in the serial monitor, you should adjust the baud rate to match the setting in your Arduino. That being said, you should use a printer controller software to control and monitor your printer such s pronterface or repetier-host.
comments.author: jjhcs1

comments.text: I do and I did Change the Baud Rate from low to highest and I use Pronterface all the time all my previous problems where caused by improper calibration. now I have Re-calibrated I am good....
comments.author: oliasmage

author: oliasmage

description.text:
This is the Dextrus robotic hand from the Open Hand Project. It's a fully 3D printable robotic hand. In this case "Fully 3D printable" means that it can be made entirely from 3D printed and commercially available off the shelf parts. As such anyone with a 3D printer can make one.  
This is still a work in progress, and is not the easiest build ever, but will be a fun project for someone that's interested in this field.

These instructions are just for printing the parts, for instructions on how to make the hand, visit here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Dextrus-v11-Robotic-Hand/ You'll need to print the following:
1 x Hand-Back.stl
1 x Hand-Back_2.stl
1 x Hand-Palm.stl
1 x Hand-Palm_2.stl
1 x Hand-Thumb.stl
1 x Hand-Thumb_Cover.stl
1 x Thumb-Joint_1.stl
1 x Thumb-Joint_2.stl
4 x Finger-Joint 1.stl
4 x Finger-Joint 2.stl
4 x Finger-Joint 3.stl
4 x Hand-Motor_Housing.stl
5 x Hand-Tensioner.stl
5 x Spool-Spool.stl I have found that all parts print best in PLA with cooling. The cooling is necessary to make sure all of the bridging is done properly. I print with no support, but you may want to add support to some parts like the thumb and thumb cover. I use a fine layer height for the spools of 0.15mm but 0.25mm for the rest of the parts. The spools seem to work much better when printed in PLA. ABS seems to have a less frictional surface so the tendons move slightly more fluidly through the fingers if they are printed in ABS. Once printed, the only clean up needed should be to remove the flat bases from the finger joints.

comments.text:
Wish you can upload V2.0 of the Dextrus Hand.
Thank you !

description.text:
I made this from a picture -> svg -> thinkercad
Mi original design had the wheel holes, but it made a mess with infill because they were to small. My original idea was to make this a customizable think, but Tinkercad has better lloking fonts to make keychains, so do it there if you like. Edit: https://tinkercad.com/things/3tYeZC58AHs

SGK did a great job of integrating several good ideas into another good idea.
Using this instead of separate bearing holders and belt clamps turns a lot of fiddly alignment and measurements into a trivial 5 minute install with perfect results every time with no measurements, and also fewer holes to drill.
I've added a few more tweaks to his design.  The previous design had the belt entering flush with the print bed which isn't quite right.  This one has a parameter for space from the bed to the belt so the belt doesn't travel at an angle.
Also, there's no need for two belt tighteners, so one of those is removed.  The SCAD code has been cleaned up and commented a bit.  The belt clamp module has been unified so that the one module can make any of the required shapes by providing the proper parameters (and global variables).  A bridging layer has been added in the belt clamp nut traps for cleaner printing.
The STL provided is an SAE model for #6 screws and GT2 belts.  Modify the SCAD for other screw or belt sizes.  The belt-to-bed spacing should only be different if you're using different bar clamps or bearings than the standard Iteration 2 Prusa parts.
NOTE that the linear bearing holder SCAD file does not use configuration.scad so the screw dimensions need to be changed there as well.

Use a drill to clear the bridge layer in the belt clamp nut traps.
Position over your print bed and drill appropriate holes in the bed to match the four mounting holes.  I use 5/8" sheet metal screws to go into 1/2" plywood.  Secure temporarily using two of these holes, then drill CLEARANCE holes into the bed for the four belt clamp screws - this gives room for the belt clamp screws to go past the "bottom" of the print and slightly into the bed when you clamp the belt.
Now remove the sled from the bed again, place nuts in the belt clamp nut traps and replace and fasten the assembly to the bed.
The belt on one side is fastened by the simple cap with teeth.
On the other side, it goes through the channel, the tightener (with screw, captive nut and ram) goes on top of that with the teeth facing up, then the plain cap goes on top of that.
